Hi,

The discussion with Joel got me thinking about resource constraint...

Normally when we refer to a fitness space or fitness landscape we're
referring to how fitness varies over the genetic encoding space with
respect to a single fitness function f(). Here I want to start by
defining a parameterised fitness function, so for each combination of
parameters we have a fitness space and thus a 'space of spaces'
(hyperspace) (For ease of visualisation I'll also assume the
parameters are continuous).

So more formally we have:

  G - Genetic data. Position in encoding space.
  f(G) - Orthodox fitness function.
  f(G, x, y) - Parameterised fitness function. Here I use two
dimensions as I find it easier to think about this stuff in 1 or 2D
but the idea isn't constrained to any particular dimensionality.


Typically the x,y here could be weightings given to different aspects
of a fitness function or we could combine two distinct fitness
functions with weights (which amounts to the same thing). So e.g.

   f(G, x, y) = (f1(G) * x) + (f2(G) * y)

Where f1() and f2() are fitness functions and f() is a fitness
function which is simply the weighted combination of f1() and f2().
Other combinations are possible, this is just a nice trivial example
to put the idea across.

Now lets consider (x,y) to be coordinates in some world where the
fitness varies depending on where you are in that world, are you in
the sea, on land, a desert, rainforest, etc. Different strategies
apply to these different regions.

Consider that each G has an (x,y) associated with it (a position in
the world), I'll refer to this combination is an Individual (I). When
we initialise a new population we can distribute I's in (x,y) using a
uniform random distribution.

We now have a basis for a new form of fitness sharing based on
position in the (x,y) space rather than the G space. In a nutshell for
a given Individual we can vary fitness depending on how densly
populated the neighbourhood of I is. So where there are 'easy' regions
in (x,y) you would get a cluster of I's, but the fitness sharing
provides a selection pressure to explore regions around those
clusters.

For asexual reproduction I would suggest that offspring(x,y) should be
a gaussian distribution around parent(x,y). And for sexual
reproduction we could take some point on the line between the two
parents.

This method potentially stands as an alternative to fitness sharing
based on G only, or you might conceive of a combination of the two
methods.

What are the benefits of this?... I believe this could provide more
complex fitness landscapes which in turn may help avoid local maxima.

Finally there's another component we can add in here which is
variation of f() over time, so f(x,t) or f(x,y,t).

Colin
